reinforcements.similarity: Both prescribe showing verifiable process evidence before making trust claims. ds-ui-0904-004 (Trust-Through-Transparency Vetting Display) prescribes showing raw verification evidence (employment, identity, background, payment history) to control-oriented hosts. communicates-003 (Trust Credential Stack) prescribes mechanism-before-promise ordering: credit check result before payment guarantee claim. Both converge on the principle that trust is built on evidence, not assertions.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence (andreas-call.txt, 3:28-3:51): Bryant explains the mechanism (credit check, pre-authorization) before the conclusion (guarantee). Andreas responds with his own process standard (excellent credit on every tenant). New evidence (kelly-call.txt, 02:09): Kelly demands information depth about the guest's nursing credentials and personal identity. Both hosts require verifiable process, not verbal assurance. Kahneman (associative coherence) and Play Bigger (Choice Supportive Bias) both explain why: evidence creates a causal chain that System 1 can process as a story, while bare claims trigger skepticism. This is now confirmed across 3 host calls (Andreas, Kelly, and Dimitri via dual-verification element) making it one of the strongest patterns in the library.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the same host need: seeing platform vetting AND personal verification data side by side. ds-ui-0904-009 (Vetting Evidence Trail) designs expandable verification cards with source attribution and dates. The Dual Verification Transparency element from the Dimitri/Cold Start run prescribes showing platform vetting alongside host-accessible personal details. Both share the principle that platform vetting should complement, not replace, the host's own judgment.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Kelly (kelly-call.txt, 02:09): 'I wanted someone who I can get a little bit more information as far as their nursing and just being more confident in who they were.' Dimitri (dimitri-call.txt, 4:56): 'Your company, but still have their information, their driver's license, because you never know.' Two independent hosts, two independent book lenses (Play Bigger and Cold Start Problem), same conclusion: the platform must show the evidence, not just the verdict. The new element adds the UI specification (expandable cards with progressive disclosure) that the Dimitri element lacked.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address control-oriented hosts who distrust platform intermediation. feels-0904-002 (Control Preservation) prescribes designing every interaction so the host feels 'I am still the decision-maker.' Earned Skepticism Respect prescribes treating third-party distrust as reasonable rather than resistant. Both converge on the principle that the platform must position itself as the host's tool, not their replacement.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Kelly (kelly-call.txt, 02:09): 'I'd prefer to just kind of work with individuals directly.' Dimitri (dimitri-call.txt, 4:56): 'I usually don't deal with third parties.' Two independent hosts express nearly identical emotional objections. Kelly's objection is about control and information access. Dimitri's is about autonomy and earned skepticism. Play Bigger's Choice Supportive Bias and Cold Start's hard-side network theory converge: the host has committed to their current approach and will rationalize it as superior unless the platform demonstrates undeniable added value while preserving their agency. This is the strongest emotional signal across all host calls involving skeptical hosts.

reinforcements.similarity: Both use side-by-side comparison card patterns to reframe the host/guest's existing mental model. ds-ui-0904-008 (Risk-Contrast Comparison Card) compares direct hosting risks against guaranteed-income hosting protections across risk dimensions. The Theodore/Greever Reframing Comparison Cards compare 'What you might expect' against 'How SplitLease works' with visual asymmetry guiding the eye toward the new approach.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Kelly needs to see risk dimensions she has never considered (payment default, damage liability, early departure). Theodore needed to see how SplitLease's process compares to Airbnb's. Both elements use the same visual pattern: muted left column (old model) and purple-accented right column (new model). The new element adds host-specific risk dimensions to the pattern while the Theodore element adds guest-specific objection reframing. Together they establish a universal 'old vs. new' comparison card pattern that applies across both sides of the marketplace.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address how platform vocabulary shapes user perception. ds-ui-0904-003 (Category-Defining Vocabulary) prescribes replacing intermediation vocabulary ('matchmaker,' 'guest/host,' 'listing') with outcome vocabulary ('guaranteed-income hosting,' 'verified occupant,' 'protected property'). communicates-006 (Agent Continuity Frame) prescribes that the platform speaks as an extension of the agent, not as a separate entity, to maintain the trust frame established in the call.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Kelly (kelly-call.txt, 01:14): Bryant says 'I work basically as a matchmaker between guests and hosts' -- this single sentence categorized Split Lease as an intermediary and triggered rejection. Library evidence (andreas-call.txt): the platform is never mentioned; trust is built with Bryant. Both elements agree that vocabulary defines category perception and that the agent's identity should carry the platform. The new element extends this to a systematic vocabulary replacement protocol across all touchpoints -- a category-design-level intervention that the library element does not address. Play Bigger's magic triangle and Kahneman's priming research converge: words prime associative networks, and wrong words prime wrong networks.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the critical handoff between human interaction and platform interaction. feels-0904-004 (Respectful Departure) designs the emotional experience of a declined host's exit to maximize warm recall for future re-engagement. works-004 (Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust) designs the priming sequence that transfers call-built trust to the platform for hosts who proceed.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Kelly declined -- her exit is the only handoff that occurred. Andreas proceeded -- his handoff was from call to platform. Both elements address the same fundamental problem (trust built with a person must persist across channels) but from opposite outcomes: Kelly's warmth must be preserved for future re-engagement, while Andreas's warmth must be transferred to immediate platform use. Play Bigger's 6-10 law and Kahneman's priming research both apply: the emotional memory from the call (warm or cold) determines the host's response to all future touchpoints.

contradictions.conflict: looks-0904-003 (Vetting Evidence Trail) uses purple verification badges (#EDEAFF background, #4B47CE text) for 'Verified' and 'Clear' status indicators. The library element looks-005 (Green Trust Badges) explicitly reserves the accent green (#2d5a3d on #e8f0eb) exclusively for verified and guaranteed elements. This is a direct token collision: the new element uses purple where the library mandates green for trust/verification badges.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: The library element has stronger evidence for its position: it is grounded in Kahneman's associative learning principle (consistent color = learned trust signal) and is reinforced across multiple runs. However, the new element's use of purple is motivated by the production style guide noting that the live system uses purple (#31135D), not green (#2d5a3d), as the primary brand color. The tokens.json file uses green, but the production system has drifted to purple. The conflict is not between elements but between tokens.json and production reality.
contradictions.recommendation: Resolve by updating tokens.json to reflect production reality. If production uses purple for trust signals, the library's green trust badge specification should be updated to purple to match. Until tokens.json is corrected, both interpretations are defensible. Flag for design system audit.

contradictions.conflict: looks-0904-001 introduces a warm amber Problem tier (#FFF8F0, #C4841D border) and a purple Category tier (rgb(252, 250, 255), #31135D border) for the discovery outreach component. looks-001 (Warm Surface Continuity) prescribes that the platform uses warm off-white backgrounds (#f6f4f0) with white surface cards, and the accent color (forest green #2d5a3d) appears sparingly and only on interactive or trust-signaling elements. The new element introduces an entirely new color family (amber/warm brown) that does not exist in the library's token system and uses purple extensively where the library reserves green.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: Both elements have strong evidence. looks-001 is grounded in Kahneman's priming research applied to visual warmth at the onboarding-to-platform transition. looks-0904-001 is grounded in Play Bigger's category design requiring visual differentiation between problem (amber) and solution (purple) tiers. The conflict arises because the library was built for hosts who have already entered the platform, while the new element addresses a pre-platform discovery touchpoint. The amber tier is designed for outreach contexts (emails, SMS landing pages) where the warm neutral platform palette has not yet been established in the host's experience.
contradictions.recommendation: Scope the amber color family to pre-platform discovery touchpoints only (outreach emails, SMS landing pages, cold-traffic pages). Once the host enters the platform, revert to the library's warm neutral palette. This resolves the conflict by treating the discovery visual system as a separate context from the in-platform visual system. Add --problem-tier-bg and --problem-tier-border as scoped tokens for discovery contexts.

extensions.gap_filled: Problem-first discovery sequence for cold outreach to hosts who have not yet entered the platform. No existing library element addresses the structural failure of solution-first pitching in discovery calls. The library's trust architecture (communicates-003) addresses how to present trust credentials after the host has engaged, but not how to open the conversation to create engagement in the first place. This is the pre-platform gap: what happens before the host ever sees the platform.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence for the principle (market the problem, not the solution -- Play Bigger's core thesis), medium confidence for the specific implementation (call script structure) because it is based on a single declined call. More host rejection calls would strengthen the specific sequencing recommendations.

extensions.gap_filled: Category anchor displacement strategy for hosts who have a strong incumbent mental model (direct hosting via nursing sites). No existing library element addresses how to displace an anchored category preference. The library addresses trust-building within the platform but not category-level reframing that must occur before the host considers the platform at all.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Play Bigger's anchoring effect research is robust, and Kelly's rejection is a textbook case of anchor-based category rejection. The risk contrast approach (surface risks the old category cannot address) is well-supported by the evidence.

extensions.gap_filled: Local social proof flywheel for pre-category hosts in geographic micro-markets. No existing library element addresses how to convert declined hosts through local adoption signals. The library's social proof patterns are limited to platform-internal contexts (reviews, ratings). This element extends social proof to pre-platform outreach for hosts who have never used the platform.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium confidence. Play Bigger's Groupthink Bias research strongly supports local social proof as a category adoption mechanism, but no direct evidence exists from Split Lease's market because the local flywheel has not been implemented. The geographic micro-market threshold (when does local adoption reach the tipping point?) is theoretical.

extensions.gap_filled: Post-rejection recovery sequence with structured category seed delivery. No existing library element addresses what happens after a host explicitly declines. The library focuses on converting engaged hosts, not re-engaging declined ones. This element fills the retention gap for hosts who never entered the funnel.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium confidence. Play Bigger's 6-10 law supports the multi-year category establishment timeline, and Kelly's warm exit (referral offer, geographic connection with Bryant) provides evidence that the relationship is recoverable. However, the specific timing (25-minute SMS, 48-hour email, 30-day dormancy) is best-practice extrapolation, not empirically validated.

extensions.gap_filled: Progressive disclosure gate that enforces problem-processing before solution-exposure in digital discovery touchpoints. No existing library element implements a dwell-based content gate for information sequencing. The library's progressive disclosure patterns (communicates-001) reveal content in sequence but do not enforce minimum engagement time with any tier.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium confidence. The cognitive principle is sound (problem-first processing opens a new mental category), but the specific dwell thresholds (4 seconds desktop, 5 seconds mobile) are design heuristics, not empirically validated durations. A/B testing would be needed to calibrate the gate.

extensions.gap_filled: Real-time vocabulary enforcement system for agent call interfaces. No existing library element addresses how to ensure agents use category-defining vocabulary during live calls. The library's vocabulary patterns are static references; this element makes them dynamic and real-time.
extensions.confidence_note: Medium confidence. The need is clearly demonstrated by Kelly's call (Bryant used 'matchmaker' which triggered category rejection). The CRM-integrated vocabulary panel is a practical design, but its effectiveness depends on agent adoption and speech-to-text accuracy, neither of which has been tested.

extensions.gap_filled: Recognized vulnerability as the gateway emotion for category adoption in discovery. No existing library element addresses how to activate the host's awareness of their own uninsured risk without triggering defensiveness. The library's emotional elements focus on trust, cognitive ease, and belonging -- not on the deliberate activation of vulnerability as a prerequisite for category openness.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. Play Bigger's core thesis (market the problem) and Kelly's rejection (no problem was surfaced) converge perfectly. The emotional sequence (calm recognition -> gentle discomfort -> relief) is supported by both cognitive bias research and category design theory.

extensions.gap_filled: Category curiosity as the minimum viable emotion for penetrating satisfied certainty in discovery. No existing library element addresses how to create curiosity in a host who is satisfied with their current approach. The library's discovery elements address honest expectation-setting (The Discovery Promise) but not the activation of curiosity in a host who has not yet decided to engage.
extensions.confidence_note: High confidence. The distinction between curiosity (approach behavior) and other emotions (fear triggers avoidance, urgency triggers resistance) is well-established in cognitive psychology. Kelly's immediate classification of 'matchmaker' as a familiar concept (which killed curiosity) versus 'guaranteed-income hosting' (which would have been unfamiliar and curiosity-inducing) demonstrates the mechanism.

new_tokens_flagged: --problem-tier-bg: #FFF8F0 (amber-tinted warm off-white for risk surfaces -- not in tokens.json)
--problem-tier-border: #C4841D (amber for risk-awareness borders -- not in tokens.json)
--tier-gap-pause: 28px (spacing for deliberate visual pause -- not in tokens.json spacing scale)
--risk-surface: #FEF0DB (amber-tinted surface for risk contexts -- not in tokens.json)
--risk-cell-bg: #FFF6E8 (lighter amber for risk data cells -- not in tokens.json)
--risk-text: #7C3A00 (dark amber text for risk content -- not in tokens.json)
--protection-cell-bg: #FAF8FF (subtle purple tint for protection cells -- not in tokens.json)
--verified-badge-bg: #EDEAFF (light purple for verification badges -- conflicts with green trust badge system)
--verified-badge-text: #4B47CE (purple badge text -- conflicts with green trust badge system)
--primary-vetting-border: rgb(109, 49, 194) 3px (secondary purple accent -- not in tokens.json)
--anchor-rule: 2px solid rgb(109, 49, 194), 40px width (headline punctuation -- not in tokens.json)
Inter and DM Sans typefaces referenced extensively -- tokens.json specifies Instrument Serif, Outfit, and IBM Plex Mono
#31135D (primary purple) used as primary brand color -- tokens.json accent is #2d5a3d (forest green)
token_compliance.recommendation: CRITICAL: tokens.json and the production style guide are out of sync. tokens.json uses a warm green palette (accent #2d5a3d) with Instrument Serif / Outfit / IBM Plex Mono typography. The production system (per Style-guide.md) uses a purple palette (#31135D) with Inter / DM Sans typography. This run's elements follow the production purple palette because that is what users actually see. RECOMMENDATION: (1) Update tokens.json to reflect production reality: replace green accent with purple primary, add Inter and DM Sans as production typefaces. (2) Create a new 'discovery' token scope for the amber/warm-brown risk-awareness colors used in pre-platform outreach. (3) Resolve the trust badge color conflict (green in tokens.json vs. purple in production) with a design system audit. Until this is resolved, all runs will flag token non-compliance because the token source does not match the production system.

arc_conflicts: The vulnerability activation in discovery (feels-0904-001) must resolve into relief within 20 seconds or it converts to resentment. If the category tier is not immediately available after the problem tier, the tension-to-relief arc breaks and the host associates Split Lease with anxiety rather than protection. The dwell gate (behaves-0904-001) enforces a 4-second minimum but has a 6-second fallback timeout -- these constraints must be carefully calibrated so the problem tier activates vulnerability without the gate preventing timely relief.

The respectful departure emotion (warmth in feels-0904-004) could conflict with the local social proof emotion (belonging in feels-0904-005) if the re-engagement notification arrives too soon after the decline. A warm departure that is followed within days by a platform notification converts warmth into 'they are tracking me.' The 30-day dormancy in behaves-0904-004 addresses this, but the timing constraint must be enforced at the system level, not just documented.

Kelly never progressed past discovery, so the emotional arc for evaluation through active_lease is entirely theoretical for this lens. The emotions listed for phases 2-7 are derived from library elements and other runs, not from Kelly's call. This is a gap, not a conflict -- but it means the emotional arc from evaluation onward has no Kelly-specific evidence.
emotional_arc_check.arc_assessment: The discovery emotional arc (curiosity -> vulnerability -> relief -> warmth) is the strongest contribution of this run. It addresses a gap no prior run has covered: the emotional sequence needed to convert a satisfied, control-oriented host who has never recognized a problem with their current approach. The arc's success depends on precise timing (curiosity must be activated before vulnerability, vulnerability must resolve into relief within 20 seconds, and the departure must end on warmth). The retention arc (belonging through local social proof) is well-designed but dependent on real-world adoption data that does not yet exist. The mid-journey arcs (evaluation through active_lease) are inherited from the library and not validated by this lens. Overall, this run's emotional contribution is concentrated in discovery and retention -- exactly the phases where Kelly's data is strongest.

discovery.note: This run's primary contribution. 14 elements address discovery across all 5 layers: problem-first sequencing, category anchor displacement, vocabulary, information hierarchy, visual hierarchy, progressive disclosure gate, vulnerability activation, curiosity, and respectful departure. Combined with library elements (System 1 Trust Gate, Trust Credential Stack, Agent Continuity Frame, Discovery Promise), discovery is the best-covered phase in the system for cold-outreach contexts.

evaluation.note: Well-covered through this run's vetting evidence trail (L2, L3, L4), risk-contrast card (L2, L3, L4), and control preservation emotional element. Combined with library elements (Anchor-Then-Advance, Trust Credential Stack, Pre-Packaged Proposal, Dual Verification Transparency), evaluation has comprehensive coverage for control-oriented hosts.

onboarding.note: Partially covered through category-defining vocabulary (L1, L2) and control preservation (L5). Library provides stronger onboarding coverage (Design for Depleted User, Bridge Human Trust, Cognitive Speed Matching). Kelly never reached onboarding, so this run contributes primarily through vocabulary and control principles, not onboarding-specific elements.

listing_creation.note: Minimally covered through category-defining vocabulary (L1, L2) and vocabulary enforcement (L4). Library provides much stronger coverage (Seven-Second Unit Description, Advisor Prompt, Format Translation). Kelly never reached listing creation, so this run's contributions are limited to vocabulary consistency.

pricing.note: Minimally covered through category anchor displacement (L1) which touches pricing as a category-defining opportunity, and the risk-contrast card which includes payment guarantee framing. Library provides comprehensive pricing coverage (Single-Sum Financial Display, Format Translation). Kelly never reached pricing.

proposal_mgmt.note: Moderately covered through vetting evidence trail (L2, L3, L4), control preservation (L5), and trust transfer (L5). Library provides strong proposal coverage (Pre-Packaged Proposal, Dual Verification). This run adds the progressive disclosure interaction pattern for vetting cards and the emotional principle that the host must feel like the decision-maker.

active_lease.note: No elements from this run address active lease. Kelly never reached this phase and Play Bigger's category design framework primarily addresses market creation (discovery/evaluation), not ongoing operations. Library provides active lease coverage through other runs (Stays Manager, review systems).

retention.note: Well-covered for the specific retention use case of pre-category host re-engagement: local social proof flywheel (L1), social proof notification (L2, L3, L4, L5), category seed card (L2, L3, L4), respectful departure (L5), belonging signal (L5). However, this is a narrow retention scenario (declined hosts). Library provides broader retention coverage through other runs.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The process pattern for category-defining vocabulary (ds-ui-0904-003) recommends replacing 'matchmaker' with 'hosting protection manager' and 'listing' with 'guaranteed-income property.' These vocabulary replacements should be tested against actual host responses before being codified. Some replacements may feel corporate or jargon-heavy ('hosting protection manager' is 3 words vs. 'matchmaker' which is 1 word).
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Conduct A/B testing on discovery call scripts: one using the current vocabulary ('matchmaker between guests and hosts'), one using the proposed vocabulary ('guaranteed-income hosting manager'). Measure discovery-to-evaluation conversion rate for each. If the new vocabulary improves conversion by 15%+ among hosts who express direct-work preference, codify it. If not, iterate on the specific word choices while maintaining the category-framing principle.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The progressive disclosure gate (behaves-0904-001) enforces a 4-second dwell on the Problem tier before revealing the Category tier. This timing is a design heuristic, not an empirically validated threshold. If the dwell time is too long, hosts will perceive the page as broken or slow. If too short, the problem will not register before the solution appears.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Implement the dwell gate with configurable timing (A/B test 2s, 4s, and 6s dwell thresholds). Measure: (1) bounce rate for each threshold, (2) scroll depth past the Problem tier, (3) follow-up question rate from hosts who view the full three-tier sequence. The optimal dwell time is the shortest duration that produces measurable problem recognition (follow-up questions) without increasing bounce rate.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The visual design uses Inter and DM Sans typefaces extensively, which conflict with tokens.json (Instrument Serif, Outfit, IBM Plex Mono). L3 elements followed the production style guide rather than the token file. This inconsistency must be resolved before implementation.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Determine which typography system is authoritative: tokens.json or the production Style-guide.md. If production has moved to Inter/DM Sans, update tokens.json. If tokens.json is the source of truth, redesign L3 elements using Instrument Serif (for anchor headlines), Outfit (for body/action text), and IBM Plex Mono (for verification data). The typographic trust triad from looks-002 (Serif for recognition, Sans for action, Mono for verification) provides the mapping framework.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The vulnerability activation element (feels-0904-001) prescribes a specific emotional sequence (calm recognition -> gentle discomfort -> relief) with a 20-second maximum tension-to-relief arc. This timing constraint has not been validated against real host responses. Some hosts may need longer to process the risk question; others may feel manipulated by the deliberate discomfort.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Test the tension-to-relief arc in live discovery calls before implementing it digitally. Have agents ask the problem-framing question ('What happens if a tenant stops paying?') and measure: (1) time from question to host response, (2) nature of response (acknowledgment, deflection, counter-question, rejection), (3) whether hosts who acknowledge the risk are more receptive to the category reveal. The 20-second constraint should be validated or adjusted based on these measurements.
